body: Snippet from: https://pastebin.com/XNETeBNm
That's really strange. Not sure why the if block changes it...

Yeah I have no idea either. The guy says (and you can tell from the log if you look closely) that if he runs just
```
scatter mpg weight
```
by itself, the output wraps like the above and the extra code lines aren't hidden correctly.

But if he runs all of the following together:
```
sysuse auto
count
descr
scatter mpg weight
```
then it works! Crazy... (this is around line 400)
Have you been able to reproduce this?
No, not on my own machine. He's using Mac and Stata 15.1
I'm also on Mac and using Stata 15.1, also Special Edition

I know Stata re-sets linesize automagically when you resize the console or GUI...but I'm pretty sure that stops if linesize is set manually, and there is no reason why the console should get "resized" during an if statement.
And it's pretty reproducible as well. Several times in the log file it shows up the same.

I asked him to try https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel/tree/linewrapping-bandaid, which moves the if block into several single-line if statements. No idea if that would fix anything, but worth a try.

Also, [Fernando Perez](https://twitter.com/fperez_org) (creator of IPython/Jupyter) [retweeted](https://twitter.com/kylebarron2/status/1055130936482951168) the existence of the Stata kernel, so maybe it'll get more traction today?
Very cool. That's what traffic stats are for!
Yeah! I'm just hoping not all mac users are having these issues...
I only just added the specific offending code today in https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel/pull/210
Why if instead of cap to gr export?

The specific reason for that is explained here: https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel/issues/197#issuecomment-427467653. It's not necessarily incredibly important that it be fixed, but I just expected it to work fine...
Does it actually cause stuff to fail or is it that the log temporarily falls out of sync?
Latter

> The specific reason for that is explained here

Commands not prepended by cap do not change `_rc` ... Ah, but this is wrapped up in include, right?
Specifically the graph temporarily falls out of sync. Basically the previous graph window still exists and a new one isn't created
If I recall, single lines are not wrapped up include, so in that case this would still fall out of sync, right?
Oh yeah.. you're right
I momentarily forgot about when I sent with include vs not
I suppose I'll revert to just using `cap noi gr export`

Doesn't that re-introduce the problem that user pointed out?

I thought the way to deal with this was to look for an error code in the program and run the plot exporting whenever there were no errors at all. It definitely worked like that at some point, can't quite remember why it changed.

> Doesn't that re-introduce the problem that user pointed out?

Yes it does, but I think that problem is pretty rare. And I have no idea how rare this new issue is. (I just had a friend with access to a mac also try it and fail to reproduce the issue.)

Currently, the program automatically adds `graph export` after every graph command. Until 1.6.0, if the graph command failed, i.e. `scatter asdf sdflk`, you'd see something like "can't export graph, no graph window".

Also, I realize I never shared screenshots:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15164633/47468543-db278a00-d7c9-11e8-922b-f54290709d21.png)
that's what the person is seeing.

Hi. I'm "the guy" 😏

Tried to upgrade to the linewrapping-bandaid version per Twitter DM from @kylebarron but got an xcrun error. I'm guessing this may be because I don't have xcode installed (including command line tools.) I can try to install what I need if I get directions. To be clear my goal is to be helpful to the project, but I am limited in tech sophistication and don't mean to pull attention away from other things.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44452336/47469221-9c3b0980-d7b4-11e8-98cc-95d5715f06ee.png)
